You overstate the case considerably.  From the article (lead authored by a med student): "Other studies of children in West Africa didn’t show a lasting 'measles shadow.'"  '“That there could be a prolonged immunosuppression is possible,” says vaccine immunologist Katie Flanagan of Monash University in Melbourne, Australia. But the study “is a long way from really proving it.” For example, researchers need to show that the kids who had measles are the ones dying from other illnesses, she says.'

In addition to protecting people from measles and providing herd immunity to the general population, the measles vaccine also protects against an immune system dysfunction caused by the measles virus.

Our adaptive immune system has been trained by encounters with all sorts of pathogens in our past. That is why people who have been infected with a disease are often protected from subsequent exposure and infection from it. Vaccines provide the same immune response without being infected.

Our immune system has memory cells (types of white blood cells) that govern the immune response by ramping up production of antibodies to a previous pathogen. It turns out that the measles virus not only causes the symptoms of measles, but also kills large numbers of these memory cells, resulting in immunological amnesia and susceptibility to reinfection.

Below is an article that demonstrates that the measles vaccine protects against the loss of immunity to previous diseases caused by exposure to measles virus. This study determined in the days before vaccination, measles was actually responsible for about half of childhood deaths from other illnesses.

http://news.sciencemag.org/biology/2015/05/measles-vaccine-protects-agai...

"So from an economist’s perspective, it’s a bit of a problem that Americans have fought so strongly against property taxes for the last 40 years."

Perhaps the American homeowner understands something about property taxes that economists do not. The reasons for the complaints are probably related to the perceived or actual unfairness of one's property tax, its unpredictable increases, and one's lack of control. Here in NJ we have generally high property taxes, but with many pockets of modest taxes. In California they have proposition 13, and an inability to move across the street (much higher taxes). Local government presides over many strange property tax algorithms.
I agree with the notion that income and estate taxes are inherently fairer, and if progressive enough, more likely to reduce inequality.

I worked as the tech coordinator for a school when the Mosaic browser changed the world. I could see what it would become. I asked the school librarians to let me know when the OED would be available online. The State of Missouri - yes, Missouri - funded availability to all schools and libraries in the state for the princely sum of $15 per year. Every rural library in every tiny town had access to the OED, something they never could have afforded.

People who treasure their paper copies forget that the OED project was scholarship and meant to track the living, changing language, perhaps the most lively language on the planet. That task can now be done better than ever the paper editions could.

I'm writing this comment on an iPad in a darkened room. I can make the print larger or smaller, brighter or dimmer, a real boon to aging eyes. I guess books will always be around. The hipsters of 2040 will tell us how much better they are than digital.

This seems like a more meaningless use of statistics than most.  It completely ignores the quality of the defense.  A team with a really good defense might be defending for most of the game, while the other team attacks and racks up a lot of points, 0.1 of a point at a time.  The result would probably be either a 0-0 tie or a 1-0 win, both of which would statistically be unexpected.
